results.content:
Great for getting up and running quickly and gaining a grasp of the core functionality. A very manageable length and done at a steady pace with the right amount of detail for an introduction course.

Rather than follow the source material directly, I was able to create my own API using the videos as a reference for how to structure my code and setup my own models, services and controllers.

Instructor is quick to respond to questions and provides in-depth answers with links to source material when required.

response.content: Hi Gordon, Thank you so much for your comprehensive review. Means a lot to me! :) Take care, Patrick
response.content_html: Hi Gordon, Thank you so much for your comprehensive review. Means a lot to me! :) Take care, Patrick

results.content:
Very professionally done. The last part requires a lot of post-work to see the connection. I'm here to combine ASP.NET Core and front-end frameworks like Vue.js, so a little unsure if this was the right course in this context, but the course is nevertheless useful to me.

I wish everything was uploaded on GitHub for every single video along the way where programming exists, so the codes can be followed along the way, and not just the codes at the end of the course that are available.

response.content: Thank you very much for your review, Tom. :) As mentioned in the course, the ServiceResponse return type and the DTOs are perfect to use with any front-end. Glad you like the GitHub repository. It's great to see your appreciation for the commits for every single lecture. Take care, Patrick
response.content_html: Thank you very much for your review, Tom. :) As mentioned in the course, the ServiceResponse return type and the DTOs are perfect to use with any front-end. Glad you like the GitHub repository. It's great to see your appreciation for the commits for every single lecture. Take care, Patrick

results.content:
First of all, I would like to express my profound gratitude at this course, as well as Patrick's great efforts definitely. I'm a self-taught amateur .Net developer of three-year experience. This course gets me to know what real professional coding is like for the first time. I've learned a ton, such as the point behind DI, repository pattern, auto mapping, and so on. 

I think chances are I will have to develop a .NET Core MVC project before long, and I will for sure apply all I've learned from this course to it. However, I am confronted with an issue on how to use JWT Token to implement cookie authentication in a .NET Core MVC project. Specifically, I have no clues about how to modify the CreateToken method in AuthRepository.cs, if necessary, and, especially, inject the needed service in Startup.cs to meet my need.  So, I would be very grateful if Patrick would tell me how to do it.

response.content:
Hi Max,
Thank you so much for your review and kind words. I really appreciate it. Regarding your question, I sent you a message. :)
Take care & stay safe,
Patrick
response.content_html:
Hi Max,
Thank you so much for your review and kind words. I really appreciate it. Regarding your question, I sent you a message. :)
Take care & stay safe,
Patrick

First of all, I would like to express my profound gratitude at this course, as well as Patrick's great efforts definitely. I'm a self-taught amateur .Net developer of three-year experience. This course gets me to know what real professional coding is like for the first time. I've learned a ton, such as the point behind DI, repository pattern, auto mapping, and so on.

I think chances are I will have to develop a .NET Core MVC project before long, and I will for sure apply all I've learned from this course to it. However, I am confronted with an issue on how to use JWT Token to implement cookie authentication in a .NET Core MVC project. Specifically, I have no clues about how to modify the CreateToken method in AuthRepository.cs, if necessary, and, especially, inject the needed service in Startup.cs to meet my need. So, I would be very grateful if Patrick would tell me how to do it.

results.content: This was a great class.  I have already done some .Net Core 3.1 services for a work but I was mostly cutting and pasting from other services.  This helped me to really understand how the services actually works.  The example and explanations for Authorization and Roles were also very helpful.  I have also never used Entity framework before and this was a excellent introduction.

results.content:
Super easy to understand and follow with simple examples and implementations. Love to watch and fun to follow.
However the method he use for insertion of using directives are a bit distracting to me. Would be great if he could add them right after typing the first keyword related with that class/library/namespace. Waiting for the code to complete till the end and returning back then adding. Also typing some methods from top of the head ( or written code on the side ) rather than intellisense is my point. 
But this does not change the result, a good course and a good tutor!

response.content: Thank you very much for your feedback! I'll keep your suggestions in mind for future lectures. :)
response.content_html: Thank you very much for your feedback! I'll keep your suggestions in mind for future lectures. :)

results.content:
The course is definitely not for the basic user, a lot of C# basic concepts are just implied, and a lot of the explanations are summarized in a way someone without a certain level of knowledge might feel lost. That being said, it seems the aim of this course is not to be introductory and long, but rather fast-paced about a specialized topic, and it kills it at that.

In addition this is the first course in this platform that from my previous knowledge I can extract to real life scenarios without asking myself "but what happens when X...".

Take care,
Patrick

results.content:
I own 169 Udemy courses, but I just can't get behind this one. Udemy won't let me refund it because I've watched 33% of it, even though they claim to have a 30 day return policy and I only bought it 3 days ago. 

It's important to know that this is not an 11 hour course. It's two 5 hour courses, where the second is the exact same course, on an older version of .NET core.

Patrick spends SOOO much time typing, and narrating what he's typing. In many cases he doesn't bother explaining what he typed, or why. He's so slow. He just tells you to type stuff and moves on, especially during the authentication part.

MOST of the course is him refactoring over and over. When you look back and think about what you've covered, it's barely anything. It's amazing how much time was spent, not really accomplishing much.

I desperately want a refund, but Udemy's 30 day policy is a scam. How can we know if we don't like the course, until we watch some of it. Not even half, they cut you off somewhere between 25% and 33%.

Do not take this course. For asp.net, either go with 1 month of Pluralsight and take Scott Allen's courses, or if you are determined to use Udemy, go with Neil Cumming's course which also covers React, but you can just skip those parts.
results.content_html:
I own 169 Udemy courses, but I just can't get behind this one. Udemy won't let me refund it because I've watched 33% of it, even though they claim to have a 30 day return policy and I only bought it 3 days ago.

It's important to know that this is not an 11 hour course. It's two 5 hour courses, where the second is the exact same course, on an older version of .NET core.

Patrick spends SOOO much time typing, and narrating what he's typing. In many cases he doesn't bother explaining what he typed, or why. He's so slow. He just tells you to type stuff and moves on, especially during the authentication part.

MOST of the course is him refactoring over and over. When you look back and think about what you've covered, it's barely anything. It's amazing how much time was spent, not really accomplishing much.

I desperately want a refund, but Udemy's 30 day policy is a scam. How can we know if we don't like the course, until we watch some of it. Not even half, they cut you off somewhere between 25% and 33%.

Do not take this course. For asp.net, either go with 1 month of Pluralsight and take Scott Allen's courses, or if you are determined to use Udemy, go with Neil Cumming's course which also covers React, but you can just skip those parts.

results.content:
I've got plenty of Web API experience through Java (Spring) and Python (Django) but just landed a job where I have to go full-stack with .net core as backend. So far, this course is short and concise and exactly what I needed to quickly get up to speed. 

I'm not sure if this is something to take up if you're rather new to Web API's, but it's a perfect course to get familiar with .net core rather quickly, precisely what I was looking for.

results.content:
Great learning reference.  All of the incremental code changes for each videos work.  The code has sufficient complexity to show key functionalities, yet simple to minimize unnecessary confusion.

I like the way Patrick points out potential problems, which are expected in a real production project, walks through the codes that create the problems, explains why and provides options to address the issue.

Most of all, I appreciate Patrick keeping up with the latest, and updated the course content without breaking the codes like in quite a few other authors.
results.content_html:
Great learning reference. All of the incremental code changes for each videos work. The code has sufficient complexity to show key functionalities, yet simple to minimize unnecessary confusion.

I like the way Patrick points out potential problems, which are expected in a real production project, walks through the codes that create the problems, explains why and provides options to address the issue.

Most of all, I appreciate Patrick keeping up with the latest, and updated the course content without breaking the codes like in quite a few other authors.

results.content: I feel like it was able to keep me engaged better because we were building a game API instead of a contrived and boring example from the real world. He covered a lot in his implementation: EF Core, migrations, .NET CORE attributes, authorization, RBAC, JWT, relations, seeding, Sqlite, Postman, hashing, salting, Automapper, Dependency Injection, etc. If one wanted a well-rounded introduction to most of the things you'd encounter in an enterprise .NET API, this will cover a good bit of it.
results.content_html: I feel like it was able to keep me engaged better because we were building a game API instead of a contrived and boring example from the real world. He covered a lot in his implementation: EF Core, migrations, .NET CORE attributes, authorization, RBAC, JWT, relations, seeding, Sqlite, Postman, hashing, salting, Automapper, Dependency Injection, etc. If one wanted a well-rounded introduction to most of the things you'd encounter in an enterprise .NET API, this will cover a good bit of it.

results.content: I like the course in general, but as someone who comes from the .Net Framework, I would have liked this content if it had contents regarding the main difference between .Net Framework and .Net core, what's new in .Net Core and why we need to use .Net Core going forward and stuff like that. To be honest, after watching 85% of the content, I felt like I didn't learn anything new [mind you, I don't know anything about .Net Core and that was the main reason why I bought this course]. I'm a bit disappointed. You might as well rename the course to "Web API using .Net Framework Jumpstart …"
